properties.Description: The Ahmednagar Fort (Ahmadnagar Qila) is located close to the Bhingar Nala near Ahmednagar in[1] Maharashtra state western India. It was the headquarters of the Ahmednagar Sultanate. In 1803, it was taken by the British during the Second Anglo-Maratha Wa

Kalsubai (Marathi: कळसूबाई शिखर) is a mountain in the Western Ghats, located in the Indian state of Maharashtra. Kalsubai is the highest peak in Maharashtra and is located in Ahilyanagar district in Akole Taluka.
A historical fort at Kharda is a tourist attraction. It commemorates the Battle of Kharda fought in March 1795 between the Maratha Confederacy under the Peshwa of Pune and the Nizam of Hyderabad.

Harishchandra Fort is a hill fort in the Ahmednagar district of India. Its history is linked with that of Malshej Ghat, Kothale village and it has played a role in guarding and controlling the surrounding region.
Bahadurgad (Marathi: बहादूरगड, "Bahadur Fort") is a fort in the Pedgaon village of Ahmednagar district in Maharashtra, India.

Ratangad (Marathi: रतनगड) is a fort in Ratanwadi, Maharashtra, India, overlooking the locale of Bhandardara, one of the oldest artificial catchment area. This fort is located in the Ahmadnagar district of Maharashtra.

Amruteshwar Temple is an intricately carved Shiva temple in Ratanwadi. It is over 1200 years old and was built by the rulers of Shilahara dynasty in the 9th century CE. This is one of twelve Shiva temples built by King Jhanjha.[1] [2] It measures 61mX36m

Shirdi also known as Sainagar) is a town and pilgrimage site in the Indian state of Maharashtra. Shirdi is located in the Rahata taluka of Ahmednagar District. It is most well known for being the home of the 19th-century Indian saint Sai Baba.

The Shri Siddheshwar temple complex in Toka village is another finest example of Yadava architecture during 12th-13th century in Marathwada region. After the establishment of the Marathi state, new temples were built during the Peshwa period.

The Siddhivinayak Temple of Siddhatek is a Hindu temple dedicated to Ganesha, the elephant-headed god of wisdom. The temple is one of the Ashtavinayaka, the eight revered shrines of Ganesha in the Indian state of Maharashtra and the only Ashtavinayaka sh

Shani Shingnapur[1] or Shani Shinganapur[2] or Shingnapur[3] is a village in the Indian state of Maharashtra. Situated in Nevasa Taluka in Ahmednagar district, the village is known for its popular temple of Shani, the Hindu god associated with the planet
Built in 1757 by Nawab Ismail Khan, this fort showcases ancient military architecture. ​ https://www.tourmyindia.com/states/maharashtra/akola.html?utm_source=chatgpt.com

properties.Places: Chhatri of Raja Man Singh I
properties.Description: The Chhatri of Raja Man Singh I, also known as Man Singh Ki Chhatri, is a historical structure located at Brahmkund, Har Ki Paidi. It is a 400-year-old monument that stands along the banks of the Ganga river. The dome of the Chhatri is intact, but the st

Narnala Fort, also known as Shahnoor Fort, is a hill fortress located in the Satpura Range of Vidarbha, Maharashtra, India. It was named after the Rajput Solanki Chaulukya ruler, Raja Narnal Singh, also known as Narnal Singh Swami. The fort was initially

Balapur Fort is a Mughal fortress in the town of Balapur in the Akola district of India. Construction on the fort was started by Mirza Azam Shah, the son of Emperor Aurangzeb and it was completed by Ismaeel Khan, the Nawab of Elichpur in 1757.
A local temple in Akola dedicated to Lord Narsing, reflecting the city's religious diversity.

The Bala Devi Temple is located just under the Balapur Fort on the southern side of the town in Akola, Maharashtra. The temple is dedicated to Bala Devi, from whom the town of Balapur has derived its name. Inside the fort, there are three wells and one m

Maa Kalanka Devi Temple – The earlier accounts mention the temple was dedicated to the goddess Bhawani and was known by the same name. The main entrance to the temple is on the north through a mandapa.

The Salasar Temple was established in the year 2014 in Ganga Nagar Akola. Here are the idols of Shri Hanumanji, Shri Ram Darbar, Shri Radhakrishna and Shri Shiv Parivar. The temple complex is 2 lakh sq ft and has a garden in it.

Antarikṣa Pārśvanātha Tīrtha is a Śvetāmbara Jain temple in Shirpur (Jain) town in Akola district, Maharashtra, India. Most popular for the main deity which is supposedly a 'floating' black-colored idol of Parshvanatha, the 23rd Tirthankara, this
An ashram dedicated to Sant Gadge Maharaj, a social reformer known for his work towards cleanliness and social equality.
A historic fort located near the Melghat Tiger Reserve, known for its architectural grandeur and strategic importance.
A historical monument in Amravati, representing the architectural heritage of the region.

Bhimkund-Kichakdara holds mythological significance that attracts tourists, especially Hindu pilgrims year-round. This is the place, where Bhima killed Kichaka and threw his body into the valley, named Kichakdara. Bhimkund is the place, where Bhima took
A museum showcasing the culture, artifacts, and lifestyle of the tribal communities in the Melghat region.
A park featuring a statue of Saint Tukdoji Maharaj, serving as a place for relaxation and reflection.
An ancient temple in Amravati dedicated to Goddess Ambadevi, believed to be the deity after whom the city is named.
A revered temple dedicated to Goddess Ekvira, attracting devotees from various regions.
Believed to be the capital of the Vidarbha Kingdom, this site houses the Rukmini Temple and holds mythological significance.
A series of 52 Jain temples located on the Satpura hills, known for their architectural beauty and religious importance.

The Aurangabad caves, are twelve rock-cut Buddhist shrines located on a hill running roughly east to west, close to the city of Aurangabad, Maharashtra. The first reference to the Aurangabad Caves is in the great chaitya of Kanheri Caves. The Aurangabad
Cave 34 is an unfinished four-pillared hall with a shrine. Another place called Samvatsarana is located in Ellora caves which was used by thirthankaras preached after attaining omniscience.

The Pitalkhora Caves, in the Satmala range of the Western Ghats of Maharashtra, India, are an ancient Buddhist site consisting of 14 rock-cut cave monuments which date back to the third century BCE, making them one of the earliest examples of rock-cut ar
Ajanta caves are essentially Buddhist monasteries of the bygone era. It is a place where Buddhist monks lived, studied and prayed.
Rock-cut temples of Hindu, Jain, and Buddhist faiths.
The magnificent palace has nine apartments, masjid, hot baths, kacheri in addition to several other structures which were subsequently ruined and later demolished.
This historical Palace is said to have derived its name from the golden paintings that adorned it in the past.

Daulatabad Fort, originally Devagiri Fort, is a historic fortified citadel located in Daulatabad village near Aurangabad, Maharashtra, India. It was the capital of the Yadavas (9th century â€“ 14th century CE), for a brief time the capital of the De
An underground water stream 6 km away from Panchakki, a tributary of Harsul River, is a source of steady water supply to this structure and is transported through earthen pipes.

Noor Darwaza is not explicitly mentioned in the provided context. However, there are several other historical gates in Aurangabad, such as Rangeen Darwaza, which is located close to the residence of the district collector and was once part of the Quil-e-
Tomb resembling the Taj Mahal, built by Aurangzeb's son.
The Chand Minar or the Tower of the Moon is a medieval tower in Daulatabad, India. The tower is located in the state of Maharashtra near the Daulatabad fort complex.
Delhi Gate in Aurangabad is a captivating piece of history, one of the many strategic gates in this city, famously called the â€œCity of Gates.â€
Naubat Darwaza is a historical gateway located in Aurangabad, Maharashtra, India. It served as a majestic entrance to Qila-e-Ark Fort and was built around 1682 in the Mughal style.

Ahilyabai Holkar (Marathi pronunciation: [əɦɪljɑbaɪ]; 31 May 1725 – 13 August 1795),[1] also spelled Ahalya Bai,[2] was the Rajamata and later the ruling queen of Indore within the Maratha Confederacy. She established Maheshwar (in Madhya Pradesh)
Dargah Baba Shah Musafir is a 17th century memorial built by Emperor Aurangzeb in the honour of Baba Shah Musafir who was the spiritual teacher of the emperor.

Janana Mahal is a palace located within the City Palace complex in Udaipur, India. It was built in the early 1600s and served as the former palace of the royal ladies. Today, it has been splendidly transformed to host regal weddings, events, and musical
Located near Delhi Gate in Rauza Bagh area of Aurangabad, Himayat Bagh is a mesmerising 400-acre garden built in the 17th century during the reign of the Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb.
Bani Begum Garden is a rather lush green site celebrating Mughal architecture and owes its name to Aurangzeb's son's wife, Bani Begum.

A reclining Buddha is an image that represents Buddha lying down and is a major iconographic theme in Buddhist art. It represents the historical Buddha during his last illness, about to enter the parinirvana.[1] He is lying on his right side, his head re
Considered to be "Atishaya Kshetra" or a miraculous site, the idol at the temple is believed to possess divine powers, solving the problems of the devotees and fulfilling their desires

Shri Khandoba Temple is located in Aurangabad, Maharashtra, India. It is situated in Satara village, approximately 5 km from Aurangabad Railway Station, and is known for its historical and architectural significance.
he Kailasha or Kailashanatha temple is the largest monolithic rock-cut structure in the world located in cave 16 of Ellora Caves in Aurangabad, Maharashtra.
it dedicated to the Hindu deity Lord Hanuman. This is one of the only three temples in India where the idol of the presiding deity, Lord Hanuman

the world heritage site of Ellora Caves. Formerly known as 'Rauzaa', which means the garden of paradise, Khuldabad is popular as the "Valley of Saints", because the city was resided by several Sufi saints in the 14th century.
Grishneshwar Jyotirlinga Temple, also known as Grishneshwar Temple, is a Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva and is one of the 12 Jyotirlingas in India.

Situated in Khuldabad village, about 25 kilometres away from Aurangabad lies the Tomb of Aurangzeb, the grave of the sixth and the last Mughal Emperor, Muhi-ud-Din Muhammad, famously known as Aurangzeb.
Medieval fort offering panoramic views; significant for its architectural design and historical importance.
Remnants of ancient city gates like Kotwali Gate and Bashir Gunj Gate; reflect the city's fortified past.
Historic well built in 1583 by Salabat Khan; known for its perennial water supply even during droughts.
One of the largest mosques in Beed, built in 1627 during Mughal Emperor Jahangir's reign; features three huge domes and four minarets.
Tomb of 14th-century Sufi saint Shahinshah Wali; an annual Urs is held here.
Spiritual hub with multiple temples and historical sites; significant for cultural studies.
Temple dedicated to Goddess Yogeshwari; significant pilgrimage site with rich cultural heritage.
Temple associated with the legend of Jatayu from the Ramayana; holds mythological significance.
Ancient Shiva temple built in black stone, situated in the middle of a lake; showcases Yadava period architecture.
Hemadpanti-style temple with two 70-foot octagonal Deepmalas (lamp towers); significant cultural landmark.
Ancient temple built during the Rashtrakuta Dynasty; known for its architectural significance.
Region known for its historical forts and temples; reflects the rich cultural tapestry of Beed.
Ancient temple dedicated to Lord Shiva; one of the twelve Jyotirlingas in India.
One of the twelve Jyotirlingas dedicated to Lord Shiva; renovated by Rani Ahilyabai Holkar in the 1700s.
Renowned temple dedicated to Lord Shiva; attracts numerous pilgrims annually.
Medieval fort built c.1700 by Gond rulers; later Maratha & British prison site (nagzirawildlifesanctuary.com, bhandara.gov.in, maharashtratourism.gov.in)
“Mahasthupa” built by Panaya Metta trust; promotes peace; tourist attraction
Established 2013; hosts tigers, leopards, sambar, gaurs, migratory Siberian birds
Part of larger tiger reserves; tigers, leopards, gaur, rich birdlife; safari available
Spreads over Bhandara & Nagpur; tigers, leopards, dhole, gaur; part of Pench corridor
A fort showcasing the architectural prowess of ancient times.
A fort with historical importance, reflecting the region's rich past.
A historical fort known for its strategic importance in the past.
A unique saltwater lake formed by a meteorite impact, surrounded by ancient temples.
A dargah revered by people of all faiths, believed to cure mental ailments.
Birthplace of Rajmata Jijau, mother of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. The Bhuikot Palace is a significant historical monument.
An eco-tourism project with gardens, temples, and water bodies, developed by Shri Gajanan Maharaj Sansthan.
A Hemadpanthi-style temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, known for its intricate carvings.
An ancient temple dedicated to Goddess Ambadevi, significant for local devotees.
A prominent temple dedicated to Goddess Renuka, considered one of the 51 Shakti Peethas.
A popular temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, attracting devotees especially during festivals.
An ancient temple dedicated to Lord Balaji, significant for its religious importance.
A 105-feet tall white marble statue of Lord Hanuman, attracting numerous visitors.
A scenic ghat with temples like Venkata Giri Balaji and Sankat Mochan Hanuman, surrounded by hills.
A revered temple dedicated to Saint Gajanan Maharaj, attracting devotees from all over.
A sanctuary named after the Dnyanganga River, rich in biodiversity and a haven for bird watchers.
A sanctuary in the Satpura ranges, home to diverse flora and fauna including tigers and leopards.

These 2,000-year-old Buddhist caves, carved during the Satavahana dynasty, feature intricate sculptures and were used for meditation and worship. The main cave extends 71 feet into the rock, ending in a chamber with a carved Buddha sculpture

Manikgad was built by the last Mana Naga King - Gahilu. The Mana Nagas settled in this area around 9 CE. Initially, the fort was named Manikagad after the patron deity of the Mana Nagas - Manikadevi - but later on this was shortened to Manikgad.
Ballarpur fort was founded by the Gond King Khandkya Ballal Sah (1437-62), who succeeded to the throne of Ser Sah, his father. He was also the founder of the Chandrapur city.

Constructed by the Gond kings between the late 15th and early 16th centuries, this fort served as a protective stronghold. Though partially in ruins, it remains a significant historical site reflecting the region's past.

A prominent Shiva temple located in Chandrapur, known for its spiritual significance and architectural beauty.
An important Jain pilgrimage site in Bhadravati, showcasing intricate carvings and serene ambiance.

An iconic temple dedicated to Goddess Mahakali, built in the 16th century by Gond king Dhundya Ram Sah. It features two entrances adorned with shrines of Lord Ganesh, Shani, and Hanuman, attracting devotees daily, especially on Tuesdays and Saturdays.

The Tadoba Andhari Tiger Reserve is a wildlife sanctuary in Chandrapur district of Maharashtra state in India. It is Maharashtra's oldest and largest national park. Created in 1955, the reserve includes the Tadoba National Park and the Andhari Wildlife S
Rock-cut caves dating back to the 6th century; dedicated to Hindu deities; notable for their historical value.
7th-century rock-cut caves originally Buddhist, later converted to Jain monuments; protected by the Archaeological Survey of India.
Ancient rock-cut caves; lesser-known but significant for historical studies.
Medieval fort named after King Nal; known for its unique basalt rock formation and man-made waterfalls.
15th-century fort built by Mahmud Gawan; features 26 bastions and a protective moat; significant in Deccan history.
Ancient temple dedicated to Lord Ganesha; known for its unique architecture and peaceful ambiance.
Jain pilgrimage site believed to be the place of salvation for Kulbhushan and Deshbhushan; features ancient temples.
Hilltop temple offering panoramic views; known for its serene environment and spiritual significance.
Ancient temple known for its intricate stone carvings and architectural significance.
Sufi shrine known for its spiritual significance and annual Urs festival attracting devotees from various communities.
Ancient town with archaeological significance; associated with early Buddhist settlements and trade routes.
Memorial temple dedicated to the 13th-century saint-poet Goroba Kumbhar; significant in the Bhakti movement.
12th-century temple dedicated to Goddess Bhavani; one of the 51 Shakti Peethas; associated with Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.
Temple dedicated to Goddess Yedeshwari; revered by local devotees; known for its spiritual ambiance.
Wildlife sanctuary established in 1997; home to diverse flora and fauna; includes the Ramling temple dedicated to Lord Shiva.

Bhamer is known for its fort known after the village name and more so for the caves or rather monks dwellings that are in the escarpments of the hills above the village. The fort located at the cast end of a rugged irregular range of rocky hills is divid

Laling Killa (Marathi: लळिंग किल्ला) is a small fort (killa) situated in the present day Dhule district of Maharashtra state in India. The fort is situated on top of Laling hill about 9.65 km (6.00 mi) south of Dhule city. It was on

The Songir fort atop the village is in the form of narrow strip 30m wide. An easy climb of 20 mins takes to the top of the fort. Songir has 3 to 4 small adjacent forts. There is a deep water well on the fort.[1] Only the door frame of the entrance of the

Thalner Fort, located in the Dhule district of Maharashtra, is one of the oldest forts in the region. Situated on the banks of the Tapi River, it has a rich historical legacy spanning several centuries.
Gond-era fort at river confluence; centrally protected heritage site (ticket2travel.is, en.wikipedia.org)
India’s first dinosaur fossil site with Jurassic‑era flora/fauna remains
“Mini‑Khajuraho” Rashtrakuta carvings; major Shiv fair at Mahashivratri
Rich in tigers, leopards, sloth bears & birds; river‑bank pilgrimage sangam
Rock-cut Paleolithic caves with stone tools; trekking
Tibetan refugee settlement with Buddhist temple & craft centre
Hilltop twin temples, believed miraculous; Navratri festivities
15th‑century Hemadpanthi Shiva temple, local pilgrimage
Mahanubhav sect temple near Bodalkasa Dam; annual fair
National park + bird sanctuary (~60 % of Maharashtra’s birds), safaris, boating (chaloghumane.com, en.wikipedia.org)
Rich in tigers, leopards, sloth bears; biodiverse forest, jeep safaris
Historic Maratha-era fort, less developed but significant heritage site.
One of the 12 Jyotirlingas of Lord Shiva, built by the Pandavas; a key pilgrimage site.

Gorakhpur takes its name from Gorakhnath, who was a saint and travelled widely across India and authored a number of texts that form a part of the canon of Nath Sampradaya. The Gorakhnath Math is a temple of the Nath monastic group of the Nath tradition.
Revered local Shiva temple, known for festivals and spiritual gatherings.
Narsi village in the district is birth place of saint shree Namdev. The saint was born in 1270 and his full name is Namdev Damaji Relekar.
Historical Jain temple, important for the Digambara Jain community.

Manudevi Temple is located near Adgaon village in Yawal Taluka, in Jalgaon district in the scenic natural surroundings of the Satpura Range, Maharashtra, India. Manudevi is the kuldevi of 70% of the people in Jalgaon district.

Shri Mangal Dev Temple of Amalner is one of the most ancient, most rare and most ‘live’ (a temple where people experience fulfillment of wishes and desires) of temples in entire India.It is public knowledge that temples of Shri Mangal Dev are very ra
Patanadevi is a historic and tourist place situated 18 km to the southwest of Chalisgaon, Maharashtra. It lies inside Gautala Autramghat Sanctuary and is surrounded by the high mountains of Sahyadri.

Padmalaya is among the two and half Ganapati peeths of India. The temple is also revered as among half Ganapati peeths. The temple has two Ganapati murtis, both are Swayambhu murtis, One idol is known as Aamod and another one is known as Pramod.[1][3]
Ancient rock-cut caves with historical significance.
Fortified town established by Jafar Khan; contains historical mosques and a cistern with inscriptions.
Built in 1725 by Kabil Khan under Nizam ul Mulk Asaf Jah I; features Persian inscriptions and a large well with galleries.
Known for the Matsyodari Devi Temple and the Dashahara festival.
Temple situated on a fish-shaped hill; significant during the Navratri festival.
Town with several temples and historical sites; offers a peaceful environment.
Birthplace of Sant Ramdas Swami; a revered pilgrimage site.
Approximately 300 years old; significant Hindu pilgrimage site.
Popular temple known for its architecture and spiritual significance.
Significant for followers of the Mahanubhava sect; associated with Sri Chakradhar Swami.
Temple dedicated to Lord Hanuman in a sleeping posture; unique architectural style.
Constructed in 1578 CE using black stone; notable for its Deccan architecture and historical significance.
Prominent temple attracting devotees, especially during Ganesh Chaturthi.

properties.Location: Near Amba Ghat (~75 km from Kolhapur)
properties.Description: Historic fort in Kolhapur district associated with Shivaji’s era
Built 1178–1209 by Shilahara, significant for Shivaji, served as Maratha capital until 1782
Historical royal durbar/palace‎ used by Kolhapur Maharajas; now houses Shahu Maharaj statue and royal memorabilia
Formed after a 9th-century earthquake; features Shalini Palace and Shiva shrine
Samadhi (tomb) of social reformer Chhatrapati Shahu Maharaj in Kolhapur
Neo‑Gothic former court built in 1876; now houses artifacts from Satavahana‑Shilahara periods
Indo‑Saracenic palace built in 1884; now a museum with royal artifacts
12th‑century Shiva temple built by King Gandaraditya of Shilahara dynasty, famed for its Svarga Mandapa
Built in the 7th century by the Chalukya dynasty; a major Shakti Peetha; features Hemadpanti architecture and hosts the Kirnotsav festival (en.wikipedia.org)

properties.Location: Wadi Ratnagiri, ~18 km NW of Kolhapur
properties.Description: Hilltop shrine dedicated to Lord Jyotiba; famous for the Chaitra Poornima fair and "pink" Gulal festival
6th-century rock-cut caves featuring sculptures of Hindu deities and a Buddha statue.
Fort built in the 16th century, surrounded by a moat; offers panoramic views of the surroundings.
A 12th-century fort known for the Battle of Udgir in 1760; features underground chambers and Persian inscriptions.
Site featuring ancient caves and temples; offers insights into the region's history.
Temple complex dedicated to Lord Balaji; includes shrines of other deities and offers daily prasadam.
Village known for the Malleppa temple of Lord Shiva; situated at the border of five villages.
Central marketplace with a unique circular design; houses a temple of Goddess Ambabai.
Temple dedicated to Lord Ganesha; known for its beautiful architecture and gardens.
Twin temples dedicated to Lord Shiva; hosts an annual fair during Mahashivratri.
Dargah built in memory of Sufi saint Saif Ullah Shaha Sardari; hosts an annual fair.
Temple featuring a 28-foot tall statue of Lord Hanuman; surrounded by a serene garden.
Temple dedicated to Goddess Renuka; known for its vibrant festivals and cultural significance.

​The Elephanta Caves are a UNESCO World Heritage Site located on Elephanta Island (also known as Gharapuri), approximately 10 kilometers east of Mumbai in Maharashtra, India. These rock-cut caves, primarily dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva, date back t

The Gloria Church, officially known as Our Lady of Glory Church (Nossa Senhora de Glória), is one of Mumbai's oldest Roman Catholic churches. Established in 1632 by Portuguese Franciscans in Mazagaon, it was rebuilt in 1911–13 in the English Gothic Re

​St. Thomas Cathedral, located in Fort, Mumbai, is the oldest Anglican church in India, consecrated in 1718. Built by the British East India Company, it stands as a Grade I heritage structure and is recognized as Mumbai's "zero point," from which all d

The St. Michael's Church in Mahim, Mumbai, is one of the city's oldest Catholic churches, originally built in 1534 by the Portuguese. Rebuilt in 1973, it is renowned for its Wednesday Novena services, attracting thousands of devotees seeking blessings.

​Bombay Castle, also known as Casa da Orta, is one of Mumbai's oldest surviving structures, located in the Fort area. Originally built by Portuguese nobleman Garcia de Orta between 1554 and 1570, it began as a manor house on land leased from the King o

​Mahim Fort is a historic fortification located in the Mahim area of Mumbai, Maharashtra. Strategically positioned in Mahim Bay, it overlooks Worli to the south, Bandra to the north, and Mahim to the east. The fort's origins are somewhat unclear, with

Sewri Fort, also known as Shivadi Fort, is a historic British-era fortification located in the Sewri neighborhood of Mumbai. Constructed in 1680 by the British East India Company, the fort was strategically positioned atop a hillock overlooking the Mumba

​Worli Fort, also known as Worli Killa, is a historic British-era fortification located in the Worli area of Mumbai. Constructed in 1675 by the British East India Company, the fort was strategically positioned atop Worli Hill to oversee Mahim Bay and s

Flora Fountain , an iconic heritage landmark in Mumbai, was built in 1864 and features a statue of Flora, the Roman goddess of flowers, symbolizing beauty and renewal. Located at Hutatma Chowk, it is surrounded by colonial architecture and serves as a ti

The Asiatic Society of Mumbai (formerly Asiatic Society of Bombay) is a learned society in the field of Asian studies based in Mumbai, India. It can trace its origin to the Literary Society of Bombay which first met in Mumbai on 26 November 1804, and was

Shivaji Park, officially Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Park, is a public park situated in Dadar, Mumbai. It is the largest park in the island city. Similar but bigger in size to Azad Maidan and August Kranti Maidan (formerly Gowalia Tank Grounds), it is of

Haji Ali Dargah, located on an islet off the coast of Worli, Mumbai, is a revered Sufi shrine dedicated to Pir Haji Ali Shah Bukhari, a 15th-century saint and former merchant from Bukhara (present-day Uzbekistan). He renounced his wealth to embark on a p

The Juma Masjid (also known as Jama Masjid) in Mumbai is one of the oldest and most significant mosques in the city. Located in the bustling area of Kalba Devi near Mohammed Ali Road, it is a prominent religious and historical landmark.

The Dr. Bhau Daji Lad Museum (formerly the Victoria & Albert Museum) is Mumbai’s oldest museum, showcasing the city’s rich cultural, industrial, and artistic heritage. Located in Byculla, it is a stunning blend of colonial architecture and modern cur

The Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu Sangrahalaya (CSMVS), formerly known as the Prince of Wales Museum, is one of Mumbai’s most prestigious museums and a treasure trove of art, history, and culture.

The National Gallery of Modern Art (NGMA) in Mumbai is one of India’s premier institutions dedicated to modern and contemporary art. Housed in a stunning heritage building, it showcases works by renowned Indian artists from the 19th century to the pres

Mani Bhavan is a historically significant museum and memorial dedicated to Mahatma Gandhi, located in Mumbai. It served as Gandhi's political headquarters in Mumbai from 1917 to 1934 and witnessed key moments in India's freedom struggle.

Shree Godiji Parshwanath Jain Derasar, located in Bhuleshwar, Mumbai, is a revered Jain temple dedicated to Lord Parshwanath, the 23rd Tirthankara. Known for its serene ambiance and intricate architecture, this derasar serves as a spiritual hub for the J

The Swaminarayan Temple in Bhuleshwar, Mumbai, is a prominent Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Swaminarayan, a revered deity in the Swaminarayan sect. Known for its traditional architecture and spiritual ambiance, the temple attracts devotees seeking bless

Shri Babulnath Temple, located in Mumbai near Girgaum Chowpatty, is a historic Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. Believed to be over 200 years old, the temple is renowned for its serene ambiance and intricate architecture, with the idol of Lord Shiva

Shri Mumbadevi Temple, located in the heart of Mumbai, is a historic Hindu temple dedicated to Goddess Mumba Devi, the patron deity of the city. Built in 1737, the temple reflects traditional Maratha architecture and attracts devotees seeking blessings f

Lalbaugcha Raja, located in Mumbai, is one of the most famous and revered Ganpati Mandals during the annual Ganesh Chaturthi festival. Established in 1934, it draws millions of devotees with its massive, intricately crafted idol of Lord Ganesha and is kn

Shri Mahalakshmi Devi Temple, located in the upscale Malabar Hill area of Mumbai, is a serene and historic temple dedicated to Goddess Mahalakshmi, the deity of wealth and prosperity. Known for its tranquil ambiance and traditional South Indian architect
Shri Walkeshwar Temple, Mumbai

Shree Siddhivinayak Temple, located in Prabhadevi, Mumbai, is one of the most famous and revered temples dedicated to Lord Ganesha. Known as the "Ganapati who grants wishes," the temple attracts millions of devotees annually with its divine ambiance, int

properties.Places: Veermata Jijabai Bhosale Botanical Udyan and Zoo
properties.Description: Veermata Jijabai Bhosale Botanical Udyan and Zoo , located in Byculla, Mumbai, is a popular botanical garden and zoo named after the mother of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. Spread over 16 hectares, it features a wide variety of flora and fauna, including

​The Mahakali Caves, also known as the Kondivite Caves, are a group of 19 ancient Buddhist rock-cut monuments located in the Andheri East suburb of Mumbai. Carved between the 1st and 6th centuries CE, these caves served as viharas (monastic dwellings)

The Mandapeshwar Caves are ancient rock-cut shrines located in the Borivali suburb of Mumbai, Maharashtra. These caves date back to the 6th–8th centuries CE and are dedicated to Lord Shiva. The name "Mandapeshwar" translates to "Lord of the Hall," refe

The Jogeshwari Caves, located in the Mumbai suburb of Jogeshwari, are among the oldest Hindu cave temples in India, dating back to the 6th century CE. These rock-cut caves are significant for their early representation of Hindu temple architecture and th

​The Kanheri Caves are a group of 109 ancient Buddhist rock-cut monuments located within Mumbai's Sanjay Gandhi National Park. Dating from the 1st century BCE to the 10th century CE, they served as a significant center for Buddhist learning and meditat

properties.Places: Basilica of Our Lady of the Mount (Mount St Mary Church)
properties.Description: ​The Basilica of Our Lady of the Mount, commonly known as Mount Mary Church, is a revered Roman Catholic basilica located in Bandra, Mumbai. Perched atop a hillock near Lands End, it offers panoramic views of the Arabian Sea and the city skyline.

​Madh Fort, also known as Versova Fort, is a historic Portuguese-era fortification located on Madh Island in northern Mumbai. Constructed in the 17th century, it served as a strategic watchtower to monitor maritime activities along the Arabian Sea.

​Sion Fort, also known as Sion Hillock Fort, is a historic British-era fortification situated atop a conical hillock in the Sion area of Mumbai. Constructed between 1669 and 1677 during the tenure of Governor Gerald Aungier, the fort served as a strate

The Global Vipassana Pagoda, located in Gorai, Mumbai, is a massive meditation hall and one of the largest stone domes in the world. Inspired by the ancient stupas of Myanmar, it serves as a center for Vipassana meditation, promoting peace, harmony, and
Prominent temple dedicated to Lord Ganesha, located on a hillock; a popular religious site.
Historic fort atop a hill, site of the Battle of Sitabuldi in 1817; houses a war memorial and Mahatma Gandhi's cell.
Monument marking the geographical center of colonial India, built by the British.
Historic lake built by Gond king Chand Sultan, with an island temple dedicated to Shiva.
Natural lake surrounded by dense forest; adjacent to the Gorewada Zoo and a proposed safari park.
Man-made lake with a garden; a tranquil spot for relaxation and leisure activities.
Scenic lake popular for boating and water sports, surrounded by forests.
Picturesque forested area ideal for trekking and picnicking; popular eco-tourism spot.
One of India's oldest museums (1863), housing tribal artifacts, coins, fossils, and ancient tools.
Sacred monument where Dr. B.R. Ambedkar embraced Buddhism with followers in 1956.
Modern Buddhist temple known for its architecture and serene environment; a symbol of Indo-Japanese friendship.
Historic temple dedicated to Lord Rama, known for its beautiful architecture and carvings.
Ancient temple dedicated to Lord Rama, believed to be his resting place during exile, located on a hilltop.
Temple dedicated to Lord Balaji (Venkateswara), known for its peaceful ambiance and spiritual significance.
Medieval fort known for its impressive architecture; has witnessed the rise and fall of several kingdoms.
Ancient fort and pilgrimage center; associated with Goddess Renuka Devi and has a rich history involving various dynasties.
Historical fort offering panoramic views; associated with various historical events and rulers.
Historic fort on the banks of the Godavari River; offers panoramic views and has significant historical importance.
Natural hot water springs believed to have medicinal properties; a serene spot for relaxation.
One of the five Takhts in Sikhism; the site where Guru Gobind Singh Ji spent his final days.
Ancient temple built in Hemadpanthi style; dedicated to Lord Shiva and known for its intricate carvings.
Sacred temple dedicated to Goddess Renuka, mother of Lord Parashurama; one of the Shakti Peethas.
Spiritual and historical city; houses temples and forts of significant Temple importance.
Annual fair and Temple gathering attracting thousands of devotees; features cultural programs and rituals.
Historic Gurudwara located on the banks of the Godavari River; significant for Sikh pilgrims.
One of the five historical Sikh shrines in Nanded; associated with Guru Gobind Singh Ji.
Temple dedicated to Lord Shiva; attracts devotees especially during Mahashivratri.
Birthplace of Saint Namdev; the temple is a significant pilgrimage site for followers.
Sanctuary known for its dry deciduous forests and diverse wildlife; offers opportunities for nature walks and bird-watching.
Protected forest area rich in biodiversity; home to various species of flora and fauna.
Prakasha, popularly known as Dakshin Kashi[citation needed]is a village situated on the bank of Tapi River in taluka Shahada in Nandurbar district, Maharashtra, India.

The Trirashmi Caves,[1] or Nashik Caves or Pandavleni is a holy Buddhist and Jain site and is located about 8 km south of the centre of Nashik (or Nasik), Maharashtra, India. Most of the caves are Viharas except for Cave 18 which is a Chaitya of the 1st

Alang Fort (also known as Alangad or Alang) is a fort located in the Kalsubai range of the Western Ghats mountains, Nashik, (Maharashtra, India). Alang Fort, Madangad Fort, Kulang Fort, and the trek connecting them are known as Alang, Madan, and Kulang (

Indrai Fort / Indragiri Fort is a fort located 75 km from Nashik, in Nashik district, of Maharashtra. This fort was surrendered to Captain Mackintosh in 1818 after the garrison in the fort saw burning of the neighboring Rajdher fort.

Harihar fort / Harshagad is a fort located 40 km from Nashik City, 48 km from Igatpuri, 40 km from Ghoti in Nashik district, of Maharashtra, India. It is an important fort in Nashik district, and was constructed to look upon the trade route through Gonda

Kulang fort (कुलंग गड ) is located in the Igatpuri area of Nashik district, on the western side of the Kalsubai hill range. This fort is adjacent to the Madangad and Alang forts, all of which were constructed to protect the Nashik-Kalyan an

Dhodap is one of the hill forts in Maharashtra state in India. Situated in Kalwan taluka in the Nashik district. the fort is 4829 ft (1472 mt) above sea level. It is the site of the second-highest fort in the Sahyadri mountains after Salher.

Kavnai Fort is located in a hillock, north of Kavanai village in Igatpuri Taluka of the Nashik district in the Indian state of Maharashtra. The main gate and a small pond are the only remaining structures.

Galna was a major fort in Malegaon talukain in the south Khandesh area of Maharashtra, India. This fort was an important fort on the Burhanpur-Surat trade route. This is one of the forts in Maharashtra with the bastion and the entrance in good condition.

Malegaon Fort is a land fort located in the town of Malegaon. It is located 104 km from Nashik, in Nashik district, of Maharashtra. The fort is on the north bank of the Mausam river, which is a tributary of the Girna river. It was built during the Marath

Ankai Fort is a historic site found in the Satmala Range hills in western India.[1][2] It is located in Yeola Taluka of Nashik district in the state of Maharashtra. The fort was built by Yadava of Devgiri. Geographically, it is near Manmad.

Salher is a place located near Salher Village in Satana tehsil in Nashik district of Maharashtra, India.The old name of Salher was Gavalgarh. It is the site of the highest fort in the Sahyadri mountains and the second highest peak at 1,567 metres (5,141

Kalaram Temple, is a Hindu temple in Nashik of Nashik district in Maharashtra, dedicated to the deity Rama. It is a temple situated in Panchavati area of the Nashik. The temple derives its name from a black statue of Rama. The literal translation of kala

The Gondeshwar Temple (IAST: Gondeśvara) is an 11th-12th century Hindu temple located in Sinnar, a town in the Nashik district of Maharashtra, India. It features a panchayatana plan; with a main shrine dedicated to Shiva; and four subsidiary shrines ded

Arnala Fort, also known as Jaldurg or Janjire Arnala, is a historic coastal fort located on Arnala Island, approximately 8 km north of Vasai in Maharashtra. Constructed in 1516 by Sultan Mahmud Begda of the Gujarat Sultanate, the fort has witnessed vario

​Jai Vilas Palace, also known as Jawhar Fort, is a historic palace located in Jawhar, a picturesque hill station in the Palghar district of Maharashtra. Constructed in 1940 by Raja Yashwantrao Mukne, the last ruler of the Mukne dynasty, the palace serv

Kelva Fort, also known as Kelva Killa, is a historic sea fort located in the Palghar district of Maharashtra, approximately 12.5 km from Palghar town. Constructed by the Portuguese in the 16th century, the fort has witnessed various rulers, including the

A significant coastal fort built by the Portuguese in the 16th century, Vasai Fort was captured by Chimaji Appa, a Maratha commander, in 1739. The fort played a pivotal role in the Maratha-Portuguese conflicts and marks the decline of Portuguese influenc

Shirgaon Fort, also known as Shirgao Fort, is a coastal fort located in Shirgaon village, Palghar district, Maharashtra. Built in 1225 AD during the Yadava dynasty, it has witnessed various rulers, including the Gujarat Sultanate, Bahamani dynasty, Ahmad

Mahalakshmi Temple in Dahanu, Maharashtra, is a serene and ancient temple dedicated to Goddess Mahalakshmi, the deity of wealth and prosperity. Nestled amidst lush greenery and tranquil surroundings, this temple attracts devotees seeking blessings for go

Shree Vajreshwari Yogini Devi Mandir located in the town of Vajreshwari near Mumbai, is a historic Hindu temple dedicated to Goddess Vajreshwari, an incarnation of Goddess Durga. Believed to have been built in the 18th century, the temple is renowned for

Jivdani Devi Temple, located on Jivdani Hill in Vashi, Navi Mumbai, is a revered shrine dedicated to Goddess Jivdani, offering devotees a serene spiritual experience and stunning views after a climb of approximately 1,200 steps.
Ancient temple dedicated to Lord Shiva; part of the 360 temples in Charthana.
Temple dedicated to the revered saint and poetess Sant Janabai.

properties.Description: Ancient Jain temple complex with caves and idols dating back to the 8th-9th century.

Sacred confluence of three rivers; significant for Temple rituals.
Temple dedicated to Lord Dattatreya; known for its serene environment.
Temple dedicated to Lord Dattatreya; known for its spiritual ambiance.
Temple dedicated to Goddess Ashtabhuja; significant for local devotees.
Temple dedicated to Lord Shiva; reconstructed in the 18th century.

Shivneri Fort (known as Killa) (Marathi pronunciation: [ʃiʋneɾiː]) is an ancient military fortification located near Junnar in Pune district in Maharashtra, India. It is the birthplace of Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, the founder of Maratha Kingdom.

Shaniwar Wada is a historical fortification in the city of Pune, India. Built in 1732,[1] it was the seat of the Peshwas of the Maratha Confederacy until 1818. The fort itself was largely destroyed in 1828 by an unexplained fire, but the surviving struct
The Lal Mahal (Red Palace) of Pune is one of the most famous monuments located in Pune, India, where Shivaji I, founder of the Maratha Empire, spent his childhood.

Bhimashankar Temple is a Hindu temple dedicated to Durga situated in its eponymous village, Bhimashankari, in Pune district of Maharashtra. It is a key pilgrimage centre and contains one of the 12 Jyotirlingas.

The Chattushringi[1] Temple also spelt as Chattushrungi Temple is a Hindu temple in the city of Pune in Maharashtra state of India.[2] The temple is located on the slope of a hill on Senapati Bapat Road.[3] It is said to have been built during the reign
The Khandoba Temple of Jejuri is a Hindu temple dedicated to the god Khandoba, located on a hill in the town of Jejuri, Maharashtra, India.

The Kasba Ganapati refers to both a particular murti of the god Ganapati in Pune, India, as well as to the temple built around the murti. The Kasba Ganapati is the presiding deity (gramadevata) of Pune.

The Ganesha temple is located in Cave 7, the largest excavation around Junnar, about 30 metres (98 ft) above the plains. It is essentially a Buddhist Vihara (a dwelling for monks, mostly with meditation cells) in design, an unpillared hall with 20 cells

Shri Mayureshwar Mandir or Shri Moreshwar Temple is a Hindu temple (mandir) dedicated to Ganesha, god of wisdom. It is located in Moragaon in Pune District, about 65 km away from Pune city in the Indian state of Maharashtra.

Shri Laxmi Narsimha Temple (popularly known as Nira Narasimha) (Marathi: श्री लक्ष्मी नृसिंह देवस्थान), is one of the oldest Hindu temples dedicated to Narasimha, an avatar of Vishnu, located in Nira Nars
The Vigneshwara Temple or Vighnahar Ganapati Temple[1] of Ozar (also spelt as Ojhar or Ojzar) is a Hindu temple dedicated to Ganesha, the elephant-headed god of wisdom.

The Dagadusheth Halwai Ganapati Temple is a Hindu temple dedicated to the Hindu god Ganesha (Ganapati) in the city of Pune, India.

Ranjangaon Ganpati also known as Shri Mahaganpati Temple is a Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Ganesha, one of the most revered deities in Hinduism. Situated in the village of Ranjangaon within the Shirur taluka of Pune district, Maharashtra, India.
The Chintamani Temple of Theur is a Hindu temple dedicated to Supreme God Ganesha according to Ganapatya Sect located 25 km (16 mi) from Pune,

The Kuda Caves are an ancient group of 26 Buddhist rock-cut caves located in the village of Kuda, near Murud-Janjira in the Raigad district of Maharashtra. These caves date back to the 1st century BCE, making them some of the earliest examples of Buddhis

​The Gandharpale Caves, also known as Pandav Leni, are a group of 30 ancient Buddhist rock-cut caves located near Mahad in Maharashtra, approximately 120 km south of Mumbai along the Mumbai-Goa Highway (NH66).

The Nenavali Caves, also known as Khadsamble Caves, are a group of approximately 37 Buddhist rock-cut caves located near Nenavali village in the Sudhagad region of Raigad district, Maharashtra. Situated about 35 km from Pali, these caves were carved duri

The Thanale Caves, also known as Nadsur Caves, are a group of 23 ancient Buddhist rock-cut caves located near Thanale village in the Sudhagad taluka of Raigad district, Maharashtra. Situated approximately 72 km southeast of Mumbai, these caves are nestle

​Shivthar Ghal, also known as Sundarmath (meaning "Beautiful Monastery"), is a historic cave located in the Sahyadri mountains near Mahad, Maharashtra. Situated approximately 34 km from Mahad, this serene spot is renowned for its spiritual significance

Konkandiva Fort (transliteration: Konkandiva Qilа̄) is a fort located 70 km from Pune in Maharashtra. This fort is on the boundary of Raigad and Pune district. The fort was important as a surveillance fort to keep watch on the possible attack on the Ra

Kothaligad (also called Kotligad/ Kothligad/Peth) is a small fort (3100 ft) situated to the east of Karjat near Karjat-Murbad Road in the Indian state of Maharashtra. It is a famous trek in the Karjat area, because of its small height and easy climbing.

Korlai Fort is a colonial fort in the Raigad district of Maharashtra, India.[2] Formerly a part of Chaul in Portuguese India,[3] the structure is a specimen of Portuguese colonial architecture.[2] It was built as a companion to the fort at Chaul, at this

Khanderi (officially Kanhoji Angre island) is an island with a fort, located south of Mumbai, along the coast of Maharashtra, India. Khanderi is located 5 km off the coast of Maharashtra (off Thal, Kihim) and 20 km south of Mumbai. Khanderi, along with i

Avchitgad (अवचितगड) is a fort located in the Sahyadri ranges of Maharashtra. The fort is situated near Roha in the Raigad district. At the base of this fort is a village called Medha and Padam - Kharapti.

Sarasgad fort is situated near village Pali in the Raigad district of Maharashtra. Pali lies about 10 kilometres East of Nagothane along the Nagothane-Khopoli road. This fort height from sea level is 490 meters. Sarasgad Fort is the twin of Sudhagad Fort

Sudhagad / Bhorapgad is a hill fort situated in Maharashtra, India. It lies about 53 kilometres (33 mi) west of Pune, 26 kilometres (16 mi) south of Lonavla and 11 kilometres (6.8 mi) east of Pali in Raigad District. The summit is 620 metres (2,030 ft) a

Prabalgad (also known as Muranjan, Pradhangad or Prabalmachi) is a fort located between Matheran and Panvel and comes under the Raigad District in the state of Maharashtra, India. The Prabalgad Fort stands at an elevation of 2,300 feet (700 m) in the Wes

Murud Janjira is the local name of a famous fort and tourist spot situated on an island just off the coastal town of Murud, in the Raigad district of Maharashtra, India. Malik Ambar is credited with the construction of the Janjira Fort in the Murud Area

Revdanda Fort (in Portuguese "Fortaleza de Chaul") is located in Revdanda, Maharashtra, India. The fort is located at the mouth of the Kundalika River. It is easily accessible by road. The Alibag-Murud road passes through the fort. Earlier the fort was g

Manikgad is a mountain fortress and temple in Gherakilla Manikgad, India. Located among rolling hills, the temple is a popular hiking spot. Manikgad was built to oversee the trade route from Maval (Pune) to coastal ports. The fort is situated near Vashiv

Dronagiri Fort is a fort in Navi Mumbai's Raigad district, Maharashtra, India. The fort is situated on the top of the hill which is close to Uran town in Raigad district. The fort is accessible in all seasons. The trek to the fort is simple and safe. Bei

The Shri Suvarna Ganesh Temple, located in Diveagar, Maharashtra, is a famous temple dedicated to Lord Ganesha. Known for its unique idol made of pure gold (hence the name "Suvarna" meaning "gold"), this temple holds immense religious and cultural import

Varadvinayak, also spelt as Varadavinayaka, is one of the Ashtavinayak temples of the Hindu deity Ganesha. It is located in Mahad village situated in Khalapur taluka near Karjat and Khopoli of Raigad District, Maharashtra, India. The temple was built (re

​Jaigad Fort, also known as Zyghur in old British records, is a historic coastal fort located in Jaigad, Ratnagiri District, Maharashtra. Perched on a cliff at the tip of a peninsula, it overlooks the bay where the Shastri River meets the Arabian Sea.

This museum is dedicated to Bal Gangadhar Tilak, one of India's foremost freedom fighters, who was born in Ratnagiri.

Kunkeshwar Temple , located in the Devgad taluka of Maharashtra's Sindhudurg district, is a revered Shiva temple and a significant pilgrimage site. Situated near the Arabian Sea, this ancient temple is known for its spiritual ambiance and scenic beauty.

Bhagwant temple is dedicated to Shri Vishnu. The uniqueness of this temple is that, this is the only one temple of Shri Vishnu all over India having Shri Vishnu’s name as BHAGAWNT. The temple is build in Hemadpanthi style in the year 1245 A.D.

Karmala is famous for the temple of Shri. Kamaladevi. There is a significance of no. 96 for the temple. The Kamala Bhavani Temple is built by Rao Raje Nimbalkar in 1727. It is considered to be the second seat of Tulajapur Tulaja Bhavani.
